dialogues.text: Remy laid out this plan, it seemed easy. We take her, force Helene and Ray to cough up the money, and then put her back. You know? Amanda gets a weekend in the country; My sister learns a lesson; And fuck it, we'll all get paid on top of it . . . I got no problem taking money from a guy like Cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were gonna handle the cops, but Bea went nuts calling the papers and hired you. Once you found the money they had Amanda and the money. So they decided to set up a fake exchange for you to witness. They got Chris Mullen to set Cheese up at the quarry for 15k and a chance to be the boss. Even though it was too late, Cheese figured out what was happening and started shooting. You have to understand, I never been around that. Everyone was panickin' and she . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . she got scared and she ran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she just fell in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was your sister's kid, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister's c h i l d .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I miss her? She was more my kid than Helene's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last summer, Helene and Dottie took Amanda to the beach. Real hot day. Amanda fell asleep and they left her in the car to go off with some guys in the dunes. For two hours. Amanda literally roasted. She was t h r e e .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister called me up later that night because Amanda was, " b e i n q a r e a l b i t c h . "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I got over there I found my niece in the bathtub, schriekin' in pain and she reeked, like beer. The best my sister could come up with to ease her daughter's pain was to douse her in cold beer. But not all of it, she wanted to "save some."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long exhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later on, I was holding her, trying to help her sleep, and she was so hot she felt like something just outta the oven... Like a fuckinr pot r o a s t .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't feel too sorry for my sister. She never cared about anyone but herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108   A COMMOTION draws their attention to the front door WEARING A POPEYE MASK stands just inside the door brandis a shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing with his gun) Right under there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender does as he's told -- sliding open a door beneath the bar to reveal a safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone needs to shut up. I'll be done in two minutes. (to the dart players) You get down on the floor. Hands behind your head! Just relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman starts to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, god, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will all be over in a minute if everyone stays calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who's bar this is, shit-head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popeye CRACKS the teamster in the jaw with the butt of hi shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you can get wise. It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender places a STACK OF BILLS on the bar -- 2 or grand. Popeye throws a DUFFLE BAG at him and he fills it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pipe down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody said anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another smart guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You1re a talker, huh? Keep yapping motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop antagonizing him! He has a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to keep talking trash? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though Lionel has said nothing, every witness at the would remember it this way. That Lionel had been talking he had been killed. Popeye SNAPS THE ROUND INTO THE CHAMBER WITH ONE HAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Patrick, this rings a bell. From the Tretts. . . Popeye is Bressant. Bressant levels the shotgun at Lionel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your eyes, Mouth. Close 'em tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMY BRESSANT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant looks at him, then sticks the shotgun between Lionel' s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes shut) Wait. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda McCready was taken by Remy Bressant !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that fucking name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already told him we did it for ransom. I told him we did it for ransom! Remy . . . Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His heart isn't in it. He begins to lower his gun

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: TWO SHOTS HIT Bressant. He takes a beat to register this, standing stock-still. The Bartender is standing there with a smoking gun, in sh Patrick leaps out of his chair and drives his head into Bressant's stomach. Wrapping his arms around his waist, h plows his spine straight back into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant cracks the shotgun stock down onto the back of Patrick's neck, buckling his knees and crashing him to th floor. He SCRAMBLES OUT the front door. Patrick gets to his feet and looks around. Angie is okay. Patrick turns and RACES out the front door after Bressant Angie goes to Lionel's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call 911! Call 911!

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: Patrick looks up and down the street, but Bressant is now to be seen. He sees a BLOODY POPEYE MASK on the ground. A TRAIL OF BLOOD runs away from it which Patrick follows ac the street. The thickening trail leads Patrick along the side of a LA 3-STORY FACTORY (in the process of being converted to lof and to a DOOR near the back. Blood is smeared on the door a small red puddle has formed on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: INT FACTORY STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: Leading with his gun, Patrick steps into a bright STAIRWE Blood tracks up the stairs and Patrick ascends cautiously He climbs one flight. And then another -- pausing on the landing. Above him, li comes through an OPEN DOOR. He starts for it. Patrick continues up the last few steps. He reaches the t and peers out onto:

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: Patrick scans the roof for Remy. He sees nothing on his r and turns around to his left, circling the stairwell. Beh him we see a magnificent view of the neighborhood. He tur another corner to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant sits against an aluminum vent - - his head leane back and his eyes half closed. A ROSE OF BLOOD spreads ou against Bressant's shirt. His flesh is beginning to grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick holds his gun on him and calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the fuckin' gun down!            Put it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy has his gun on his lap. He lets it fall to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bartender wasn't fuckin' around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick kicks away the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. You let this little girl die. You want to tell me how to live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick looks at Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Do your best.' Fuck you, this is my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant wags his head a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know? You let a girl go off a cliff. What do you know? You don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant just smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a child--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy gives him a long, strange look. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never have kids. I told my wife to marry someone else. She wouldn't do it. (beat, distant) I love children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bressant is fading. Patrick stands over him. Oddly peacef Bressant gives Patrick a kind smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, Patrick. You get to Florida, look me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick stands there. Bressant looks out at Boston, risin steel and glass in the setting August sun. Autumn is almo at hand and the crispness of the air makes the view all t more sad. Bressant makes a guttural sound, appreciating the last th he'll see. Patrick looks at him, dying. Not how he expected this to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE starts on Remy, up to Patrick, then pulls far above both them and the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick sits in a chair. Present are the NEW CAPTAIN (57) a BEEFY OFFICER (50) with a crew cut. They sit around a desk, informally. Patrick is not charge with anything but rather is being questioned routinely (hence, no lawyer) .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I expose a conspiracy I was a part of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Lionel contradict anything I said? Did the witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Police officer was killed today. That's not looked on lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is corruption looked on lightly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a smart mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is getting a little girl killed looked on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd like to ensure that you're telling us the truth. Is that all right with you? Hot shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, hot shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, after setting up Jean Baptiste, your friend Chris Mullen was coincidentally killed? And you didn't have nothing to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was probably killed by Sgt. Detective Remy Bressant or anyone else who wanted the 130K in his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You charge money as a detective. But you were at the quarry and yet you had no idea it was a set up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust the Police when they tell me something. And I had a fake ransom note and Amanda's blanket the cops left in my mailbox. And I heard the tape from when Cheese, or I guess it was Chris pretending to be Cheese, called the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 911 call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The call into the station from Cheese to Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't tape calls into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we don't do transcripts, smart guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. This causes Patrick to register something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear a tape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see a transcript?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have remembered it wrong. Remy read it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I've cooperated. Unless you want me to go out there and start calling the papers to give 'em my Police corruption exclusive, I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're released. But Mr. Kenize--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't get pulled over any time soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick comes into the office/living room. Angie is there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kept my shoelaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go down to Zayre's tomorrow and get you some new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to do that tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a trip.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MASS TURNPIKE
dialogues.text: The car speeds along the empty highway, carving through t forests of pine trees. Inside the car it's quiet. Patrick's stare is fixed to th road -- the rhythm of the white lines that pulse by. Angi rests her head against the passenger window, the BLUR of tree-line reflected in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . RURAL HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: A 2-LANE ROAD winds them through rolling hills and past a SIGN welcoming them to: 'WEST BECKETT, MA. Pop. 974' -- a Rockwell painting in the heart of the Berkshire Mountains

dialogues.speaker: EXT TOWNSEND ROAD
dialogues.text: The car rolls down a quiet road where small COTTAGES nest in clumps of birch and pine trees. Patrick parks opposite long driveway. A MAILBOX at its mouth reads: DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Angie sit in the car.   They look down a driv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to tell me where our trip has taken us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would never, ever do something to endanger a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a part of it. They don't tape calls. He handed us a transcript like it was evidence and he knew it was a forgery- -maybe he forged it himself. He knew what they were doing, he supported it and he covered it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? For a third of a hundred and thirty grand? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to be for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're talking about ruining an old man who lost his child and gave years of service . . . "something" isn't enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a guy who tried to ruin us, something' s plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kind of thing where if you do it, you want to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he goes down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start down the driveway towards a small, red cottage a hundred yards or so off the road. But after only a few steps, they stop. PATRICK & ANGIE'S POV: Through the trees, Doyle emerg the cottage. He carries 2 FULL SUITCASES to a SUBURBAN an loads them in the back. His wife, FRANCINE, follows. Patrick & Angie take a beat before resuming down the Only to FREEZE IN THEIR TRACKS at the sight of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMANDA MCCREADY CHARGING ONTO THE PORCH, clutching a BACK PACK, and wearing a look of utter determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget mine, gramma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never forget yours, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle lifts Amanda off the porch and carries her to the Suburban. He dips down, allowing Amanda to place her back pack inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a, please a sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind do you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grill Cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the crusts on, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled with this game) Noooo! I don't like the crusts on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That' s right, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Angie have ducked into the woods. They are bo in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's alive. SERIES OF FLASHBACKS SHOWING WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENED IN EXTREMELY QUICK SUCCESSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick walks down Doyle's driveway toward the car. Angie sitting, leaned up against the hood, he head tilted forwa As Patrick draws near, she lifts her head up to him and w see she has been crying. This isn't what Patrick expected and he is taken aback fo beat, long enough for Angie to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She' s happy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angie, don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you call the Police they'll send her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you on my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am on your side but I can't send her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sending her anywhere. That's her mother. She has a right to her child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's better for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Because he has money and makes sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he loves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene loves her, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might learn from this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   People don't change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle grows more impassioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene is arsenic. She'll kill her. She'll burn the life out of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't take away someone's kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to.   I want to leave their child with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~ l this time we wanted to bring her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: home. Why is that wrong now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I know right and wrong when I see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to understand me right now. I need you to love me and say I know this is a hard decision but I stand by you. I need you to take me home and make this okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do that. I can take you home and I know how to make it okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be okay because every now and again we'll talk about her and where she might be and what grade she's in and we'll be proud of her and that will be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we'll know she's in a good school and safe and has sleep overs and birthday parties and smiles every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe sometime we'll drive out here and watch a softball game with a teenager in it from the back bleachers and we'll see how much she's grown. And then I'll take you home and we' 11 know it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ask me to do something I can't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ask me to live with it,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, for me. Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hate you for doing it.   I don't want to but I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away, leaving him alone by the side of the road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in, approaching Doyle who turns to see Patrick. Doyle watches Patrick. He offers a measured greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick Kenzie. To what do I owe the pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds Doyle's look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy Bressant died last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told. It's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to understand.    He seemed like a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a good man. You don't know why people do what they do. Only they see out their own windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, AMANDA walks out the door, running to Jack and clinging to his leg. Jack holds Patrick's look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papapa.    Come make sandwiches now please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle smiles, giving away nothing of his tension with Patrick. Francine comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go inside, my sweet. I'll be there soon and make you a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francine hesitates.    Doyle is gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francine takes her back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.   Doyle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know. Good for you. You uncovered the thing men died for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men killed for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving that little girl a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your life to give. Helene is her mother. You think she's a bad mother you should have gone to social services. Short of that, it's her mother, it's where she belongs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around, get back in your car and wait thirty years. You don't know what the world is made of yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm tired of being lied to   and tired of being lectured by a gang   of criminals. I'm calling the State    Police in five minutes. They'll be here    in ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't made that call because you think it might be an irreparable mistake. Because part of you believes it doesn't matter what the rules say. Because you know, when the lights go out and it's just you and your conscience you ask yourself if she's better here or better there, you know the answer and you always will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you at the arraignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do one good pure thing here today. One right thing. Most men don't get that chance in a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walk away from that, you may not regret it when you get home, or in a year but I promise you, get to where I am, you will. But I'll be dead by then, you'll be old, and she'll be trailing a ragged, tattered childhood of her own -- and you'll be the one who has to tell them you' re sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess I will. I'll tell them I'm sorry and I'll live with it. And maybe that will happen, what I'm not gonna do, is have to apologize to a grown woman who says, why did you leave me? I got kidnapped, my aunt hired you to find me, and you did. You found me with a strange family but you broke your promise and you left me there. Why? Why didn't you bring me home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't matter how many outfits and snacks and family trips we took-- they weren't my family, they stole me and I was raised as a stranger to myself and the life I would have had. You knew about it, you knew better and you did nothing. And maybe that grown woman will forgive me but I won't forgive myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I care about is that little girl. And I'm gonna bring her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle hears this. Has his reaction, something like a sagging, an emptiness, and a resolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll have to excuse me. have a sandwich left to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Patrick watches from down the road. Doyle is on the porch Jack sits in his favorite chair. Amanda is on his    lap, facing him, arms around his shoulders, head tucked   into neck. He slowly rocks the chair. He holds Amanda     like the last hug of his life. His eyes are fixed on a    poin somewhere far off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick takes out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance sirens wail faintly, getting louder. Just inside the door is Amanda's colorful kids back-pack, strange and cute stuffed snake, and Francine's bag spilli over with zip-locked snacks and children's cups-- all the stuff Francine had packed to make sure Amanda would have, whereever she'd go. Over this all, beginning faintly and growing increasingly audible, is the inanity of the television news. It's blat like a merciless blanket of idiocy over something hopeles sad. A swarm of West Beckett POLICE CRUISERS cram the small ro A Deputy knocks on the door. Doyle answers. He knows the local cops' who are embarrassed to arrest him. He makes i easy for them. Doyle nods at the deputy with quiet acceptance and the dignity of a man at peace with the choices h e r s made. The DEPUTY puts a hand-cuffed Doyle into the back of his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francine Doyle silently mouthing! "oh my God' oh my God." Angie looks out from the car' past the policef past everything. They move to Francine to put her in a police car. dialogues.text: Patrick sits next to Amanda on the couch . . . And togeth silently -- they watch TV. Patrick sees that Amanda is holding her famous doll, the the papers said she loved so much, the one Angie plucked the quarry..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started going to Church again. I saw them bury Remy and, for the first time in years, maybe ever, I prayed for someone. I did everything I wanted to do. I proved my father wrong. I either learned my lesson or became a man, I can't tell the difference . Either way, all it' s left me is the hollow, copper aftertaste in my throat, like a vague and distant regret. Remy was right, I know very little--but what I do know, I am sure of: I was wrong about that commercial. "Shouldn' t your dog be treated like a member of the family?" It doesn't depend on the dog. It depends on the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold on them for an extended beat. The blather from th television washes over them, the man and the little girl.
